awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds research in economic theory that examines the determinants and implications of biased perceptions and beliefs. There are three components to this proposal. The first two study biased perceptions in the context of social interactions. The team is especially interested in understanding what kinds of misperceptions about society are likely to arise when people interact with only a non-representative sample of the population, and how such misperceptions affect people's ability to learn from their social contacts. The third component focuses on a type of bias that may affect individual decision making, called belief distortion. The research will give us new tools to understand and predict the outcomes of social interactions and decision-making under uncertainty. These are key to understanding many economic decisions. As a result, the project may eventually give us better ways to predict the effects of economic policies designed to promote the national interest.

The first project in the proposal builds and analyzes a model of local interaction games with coordination motives. The goal is to understand what forms of misperceptions about population characteristics and social interaction patterns can arise, and how these misperceptions affect behavior and economic welfare. The second project studies how individuals' misperceptions about their societies affect social learning about unknown fundamentals. One surprising prediction is that even under arbitrarily small amounts of misperception, information aggregation may break down completely. The third project develops an axiomatic model of belief distortion. The aim is to provide a unified framework to understand central examples of belief distortion, such as ambiguity aversion and regret, that have been widely observed. The team also wants to use this new framework to analyze the behavioral implications of additional phenomena such as motivated cognition that thus far are not well understood in terms of choice theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant resulted in five published papers. The first three papers (joint with Yuhta Ishii) are motivated by growing evidence that people's learning is often governed by a biased, simplified, or, for short, misspecified view of their environment. "Misinterpreting Others and the Fragility of Social Learning" (Econometrica, 2020) exhibits a natural setting---social learning among heterogeneous individuals---where even slight amounts of misspecification have stark consequences: Arbitrarily small misperceptions about each other's characteristics (e.g., tastes, risk attitudes) can lead all agents to grow confident in an arbitrarily incorrect state of the world---even though correctly specified agents would learn the true state. This suggests that it is important to analyze misspecified learning in its own right, as standard, correctly specified learning models may provide poor approximations. To this end, "Belief Convergence under Misspecified Learning: A Martingale Approach" (Review of Economic Studies, forthcoming) develops a general methodology to study long-run beliefs and behavior under a broad class of misspecifications and learning environments. Our analysis clarifies which features of an environment render learning outcomes especially sensitive to misspecification. "Dispersed Behavior and Perceptions in Assortative Societies" (American Economic Review, 2022) studies strategic interactions under a natural form of bias, assortativity neglect: People are more likely to interact with others who are similar to them---along income, political attitudes, etc.---but often misperceive their peers to be more representative of society than actual. We show how this bias amplifies action dispersion (e.g., the socioeconomic education investment gap) and exacerbates the effect of social changes such as increased residential segregation. Our results also shed light on empirically documented misperceptions of key population characteristics, for example, under-/overestimation of income inequality or political polarization. 

 

The final two papers contribute to the study of preferences under ambiguity (i.e., uncertainty that cannot be quantified by a single probabilistic belief), which play an important role in settings such as financial markets or insurance choice. Many central ambiguity models assume very pessimistic ambiguity attitudes: Agents evaluate ambiguous prospects using their worst conceivable belief. In "Dual-Self Representations of Ambiguity Preferences" (with Madhav Chandrasekher and Yves Le Yaouanq, Econometrica, 2022), we propose a dual-self perspective on ambiguity preferences, by modeling agents' beliefs as the outcome of a game between Pessimism and Optimism. Our model provides a unified framework to organize rich experimental evidence that individuals display a mix of ambiguity-averse and ambiguity-seeking tendencies, and to explore the economic implications of such patterns. In both this paper and "Objective Rationality Foundations for (Dynamic) alpha-MEU" (with Le Yaouanq, Journal of Economic Theory, 2022), we also study how to define satisfactory belief-updating rules under ambiguity, which is essential for dynamic applications. In particular, we point out that prior-by-prior updating, the most popular updating rule in applied work, can be ill-defined if some degree of ambiguity-seeking is allowed; we then provide foundations for alternative approaches that overcome this issue.
